The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail
And you are stayed for. There
And these few precepts in thy memory
<span class=""quote"">Look thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue
Nor any unproportioned thought his act.
''Be thou familiar
''Those friends thou hast
''Grapple them unto thy soul with hoops of steel
''But do not dull thy palm with entertainment
''Of each new-hatched
''Of entrance to a quarrel
''Bear 't that th' opposÃ¨d may beware of thee.
Give every man thy ear
Take each man's censure
''Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy
''But not expressed in fancy (rich
''For the apparel oft proclaims the man
And they in France of the best rank and station
Are of a most select and generous chief in that.
Neither a borrower nor a lender be
For loan oft loses both itself and friend
And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.
''This above all: to thine own self be true
And it must follow
Thou canst not then be false to any man.

Farewell. My blessing season this in thee.";"* The commonplace markers at tzeh begginning of certain lines appear in the 1603 Folio edition of Hamlet (sig. C2 recto-2verso).";"";"@001259_A00_D23 Hamlet";"";"WoPa#030081 Polonius' advice to Laertes / SuId#004414 listen

column1: I'll offer my advice! I once observed
In a Tragedy of ours
Was acted to the life
Forced by the terror of a wounded conscience
To make discovery of that
Could not wring from him. Nor can it appear
Like an impossibility
Your Father looking on a covetous man
Presented on the Stage as in a mirror
May see his own deformity

Prepared for such to howl in

After this sleep of death.

It may bring terror
What 'tis to die

It vanisht as a Tapers light
Goes out when Spirits appear in sight.
One would have thought t'had heard <span class=""quote"">the morning crow
Or seen her well-appointed Star
Come marching up the Eastern Hill afar.
Nor durst it <span class=""quote"">in Philippi's field appear
But unseen attaqu'ed thee there.
Had it presum'ed in any shape thee to oppose
Thou wouldst have foro'ed it back upon thy foes:

column1: <span class=""quote"">Let's have a Dance upon the heath
We gain more life by Duncons death
Sometimes like brinded Cats we shew
Having no Musick but our mew;
Sometimes we dance in some old Mill
Upon the Hopper
To some old Saw
While still the Mill-clack does keep time.
Sometimes about a hallow tree
A round
Thither the chirping Critick comes
And Beetles singing drowsie humms.
Sometimes we dance o're Fens and Furs
To howl of Wolves
And when with none of these we meet

We dance to the ecchoes of our feet. ";"";"";"@005278 The New Academy of Compliments";"";"WoPa_CulMus#004054 let's have a dance";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Anthology";"";"";"ANTHOLOGY ENTRY";"MQ_GENRE / MQ_TYPOGRAPHY_Heading";"Shakespeare Studies";"@010000-2:167.";"";"";"Danneck Martin"

column1: My Hair starts up
Pity and fear raise my concern still higher
'Till
When curs'd Iago
Work up the noble Moore to Jealousie
How cunningly the Villain weaves his sin
And how the other takes the Poison in;
Or when I hear his God-like Romans rage
And by what just degrees he does asswage
Their fiery temper
Make 'em both weep
When these and other such-like Scenes I scan
'Tis then
column3: I think thee more than Man!";"Gould

column1: To kiss
To cherish and caress me so
And now not let but bid me go?
Oh Woman! Frailty is thy name
Since she's untrue y'are all to blame
And but in man no truth is sound:
'Tis a fair Sex
But (on my conscience) could we prove it

They all are false even under ground.";"";"";"@005343 Poems on Several Occasions";"";"WoTo_GenWom#004143 woman's frailty";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Poetry unspecified";"";"First-person narrator";"BODY OF TEXT";"MQ_VERBAL_Generalization";"Fulltext database";"@010001-Last accessed 13 March 2007.";"How could you once so kind appear
To kiss
To cherish and caress me so
And now not let but bid me go?
Oh Woman! Frailty is thy name
Since she's untrue y'are all to blame
And but in man no truth is sound:
'Tis a fair Sex
But (on my conscience) could we prove it
They all are false ev'n under ground.";"Cotton
